issue.title: Redundant const in the return type of any_cast(const any&)

discussion.p: The overload of any_cast that accepts a reference to constant any:

blockquote.pre: template<class ValueType> ValueType any_cast(const any& operand);

discussion.p: is specified to return *any_cast<add_const_t<remove_reference_t<ValueType>>>(&operand) in [any.nonmembers]/5. This calls the pointer-to-constant overload of any_cast:

blockquote.pre: template<class ValueType> const ValueType* any_cast(const any* operand) noexcept;

discussion.blockquote: Returns: If operand != nullptr && operand->type() == typeid(ValueType), a pointer to the object contained by operand; otherwise, nullptr.
discussion.p: Since typeid(T) == typeid(const T) for all types T, any_cast<add_const_t<T>>(&operand) is equivalent to any_cast<T>(&operand) for all types T when operand is a constant lvalue any. The add_const_t in the return specification of the first overload above is therefore redundant.
Casey will provide combined wording for this and , since they modify the same paragraph.

blockquote.p: This wording is relative to N4606.

-4- Requires: is_reference_v<ValueType> is true or is_copy_constructible_v<ValueType> is true. Otherwise the program is ill-formed.
-5- Returns: For the first form, *any_cast<add_const_t<remove_reference_t<ValueType>>>(&operand). For the second and third forms, *any_cast<remove_reference_t<ValueType>>(&operand).

discussion.note: 2016-10-05, Tomasz and Casey reopen and improve the wording
discussion.p: The constraints placed on the non-pointer any_cast overloads are neither necessary nor sufficient to guarantee that the specified effects are well-formed. The current PR for LWG also makes it possible to retrieve a dangling lvalue reference to a temporary any with e.g. any_cast<int&>(any{42}), which should be forbidden.

resolution.p: This wording is relative to N4606.

blockquote.p:
-4- Requires: is_reference_v<ValueType> is true or is_copy_constructible_v<ValueType> is true.For the first overload, is_constructible_v<ValueType, const remove_reference_t<remove_cv_t<ValueType>>&> is true. For the second overload, is_constructible_v<ValueType, remove_reference_t<remove_cv_t<ValueType>>&> is true. For the third overload, is_constructible_v<ValueType, remove_reference_t<remove_cv_t<ValueType>>> is true. Otherwise the program is ill-formed.
